questions.text: Which of the following hormones is not secreted by the pancreatic gland?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Insulin, somatostatin, and pancreatic polypeptide are all secreted by distinct cell types within the pancreatic islets (Islets of Langerhans).
  • The endocrine pancreas is made up of clusters of cells called the Islets of Langerhans, which secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream.
  • There are four major types of cells:
    • Alpha (α) cells → Secrete glucagon, which raises blood glucose.
    • Beta (β) cells → Secrete insulin, which lowers blood glucose. (Option A ruled out)
    • Delta (δ) cells → Secrete somatostatin, which inhibits both insulin and glucagon secretion, exerting a paracrine regulatory effect. (Option B ruled out)
    • PP (F) cells → Secrete pancreatic polypeptide, involved in regulating intestinal ion and water transport, and also inhibits pancreatic exocrine secretion. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient underwent a total pancreatectomy due to pancreatic carcinoma. Despite complete removal of the pancreas, laboratory evaluation showed persistent mild insulin-like activity in plasma that could not be neutralised by anti-insulin antibodies. This persistent insulin-like effect is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Persistent insulin-like activity in plasma even after pancreatectomy is primarily due to IGF-II, a major contributor to NSILA (non-suppressible insulin-like activity).

  • NSILA refers to insulin-like effects observed in plasma that are not blocked by anti-insulin antibodies.
  • It means that this activity is not reduced by anti-insulin antibodies produced due to a reaction with the insulin injected from other species or some autoimmunity.
  • These effects persist even in individuals with destroyed or removed pancreas (e.g., post-pancreatectomy), proving they are not due to insulin.
  • The activity originates from circulating Insulin-like Growth Factors (IGF-I and IGF-II), especially IGF-II, which mimics insulin in many tissues but with lower potency.
  • NSILA plays a role in glucose uptake, lipogenesis, and protein synthesis, similar to insulin, but less potent.
  • This phenomenon also helps explain why complete insulin absence does not eliminate all insulin-like actions in the body.

Explanation of other options:

Insulin (Option A): Not present after total pancreatectomy; NSILA persists despite its absence.

Proinsulin (Option C): Prohormone of insulin, secreted from β-cells; absent after pancreatectomy.

Somatostatin (Option D): Inhibitory hormone; does not exhibit insulin-like activity.

choices.text: Increased transport of glucose in the insulin-sensitive cells

questions.text: Which of the following is/are function/s of insulin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Insulin promotes nutrient storage by enhancing glucose uptake, protein synthesis, and inhibiting catabolic enzymes like phosphorylase.

- Insulin is also called the hormone of abundance. Its net effect is an increase in storage of carbohydrate, protein and fat.

- Actions of insulin on metabolism are:

  • Carbohydrate metabolism:
    • Increase entry of glucose in sensitive cells (liver, skeletal muscle, adipose tissue)
    • Increase glycogen synthase
    • Increase in glycolysis
    • Inhibit phosphorylase and gluconeogenic enzymes
  • Fat metabolism:
    • Increase in lipogenic activity
  • Protein metabolism:
    • Inhibit protein degradation
    • Increase protein synthesis

questions.text: There are various glucose transporters present in different cells of the body. Which of the following GLUTs is insulin sensitive?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

GLUT 4 is the only insulin-sensitive glucose transporter, crucial for increasing glucose uptake in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. Insulin triggers PI3K-Akt signalling, causing GLUT 4 translocation to the plasma membrane.

  • GLUTs are membrane proteins enabling facilitated diffusion of glucose, each with tissue-specific roles.
  • GLUT 2 (liver, pancreatic β-cells, kidneys): High capacity, low affinity, insulin-independent; acts as a glucose sensor.
  • GLUT 1 & GLUT 3 (brain, RBCs, kidney, retina): Maintain basal glucose uptake, independent of insulin.
  • GLUT 5 (jejunum, sperm): Specific for fructose transport.
  • GLUT 7 (liver): Transports glucose-6-phosphate within hepatocytes.

These GLUTs coordinate tissue-specific glucose handling, ensuring systemic energy balance.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: Which of the following increases the entry of glucose into the cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glucose entry into cells is promoted by insulin and exercise, each using distinct but complementary mechanisms.

  • GLUT 4 translocation: Insulin stimulates the PI3K-Akt pathway, causing vesicles containing GLUT 4 to fuse with the plasma membrane in muscle and adipose tissue, allowing glucose uptake. (Option A)
  • Glucokinase induction in liver: Insulin upregulates glucokinase, which phosphorylates glucose, keeping intracellular free glucose low and favouring further diffusion of glucose into (Option B)
  • AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK): In skeletal muscle, AMPK activation during exercise independently promotes GLUT 4 translocation, enhancing glucose uptake even without insulin. (Option C)

questions.text: What is the cause of hypokalemia in type 1 diabetic patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In type 1 diabetes, especially during treatment with exogenous insulin, there is a rapid intracellular shift of K+, which can result in hypokalemia, particularly if potassium is not supplemented.
  • Clinically, this mechanism is exploited in managing hyperkalemia - infusion of insulin and glucose reduces plasma K+ levels.

Explanation of other options:

Hypoglycemia (Option A): does not shift K+into cells; hence, not a cause of hypokalemia.

Polydipsia (Option C): Polydipsia results from osmotic diuresis in hyperglycemia and does not directly affect potassium distribution.

Key Takeaway:

  • Infusions of insulin and glucose significantly lower the plasma K+ level in normal individuals. It is effective in the treatment of hyperkalemia in patients with renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Metabolic Syndrome (Syndrome X) are true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperinsulinemia in Syndrome X results from insulin resistance (not increased sensitivity), and dyslipidemia involves increased triglycerides and decreased HDL, not LDL elevation alone.

  • Metabolic syndrome is a cluster of conditions including central obesity, insulin resistance, hyperinsulinemia, dyslipidemia (increased triglycerides, decreased HDL), and hypertension.
  • Endothelial dysfunction due to hyperglycemia and abnormal lipid levels contributes to atherosclerosis.
  • Central (visceral) obesity is a hallmark criterion in most diagnostic definitions of metabolic syndrome.
